messages.content: if I'm traveling and i get home at asr time should i shorten and combine thuhur and asr?

In Islam, the practice of shortening and combining prayers is a concession given to Muslims who are traveling (a journey that exceeds 48 miles or approximately 78 kilometers, according to many scholars). 

For the Dhuhr and Asr prayers, a traveling Muslim is allowed to shorten these 4-rak'ah prayers to 2 rak'ahs each. They can also be combined at the time of either Dhuhr or Asr, which means you can pray them at the same time to ease your travel.

However, if you arrive home at the time of Asr, you're no longer considered a traveler, so the concession of shortening and combining the prayers wouldn't apply in this case. You would perform your Asr prayer as you usually would at home. If you haven't performed your Dhuhr prayer yet, you should make it up without shortening, as you're no longer traveling. 

Please consult with a knowledgeable local religious authority or scholar if you have specific questions about your situation, as the details of Islamic jurisprudence can vary based on your specific circumstances, the Islamic school of thought you follow, and other factors. The above is a general guideline and may not be accurate for every individual's circumstances.
so i'd pray thuhur like i missed it?

Yes, if you have missed your Dhuhr prayer and you arrive home at the time of Asr, you would need to make up the Dhuhr prayer that you missed. In Islamic terminology, this is known as Qada. Qada is the Islamic concept of making up missed obligatory prayers.

So you would perform the missed Dhuhr prayer with its full 4 rak'ahs, as you are no longer considered a traveler once you reach home. After completing the Qada of Dhuhr, you should then pray the Asr prayer as usual. 

Again, this is a general guideline and practices can vary among different schools of Islamic jurisprudence. For any specific circumstances, it's always a good idea to consult with a knowledgeable local Islamic authority or scholar.
although I was traveling for thuhur - so I didn't really miss it, no?

If you were traveling during the time of Dhuhr and didn't get a chance to pray until you reached home at the time of Asr, then according to many scholars, you can still take advantage of the travel concession. That means, although you are now home, you can make up the Dhuhr prayer by praying it shortened, i.e., 2 rak'ahs instead of 4, because the time for Dhuhr occurred while you were traveling.

However, as the practices can vary among different schools of thought, it's always recommended to consult with a knowledgeable Islamic scholar or authority in your community who can provide guidance based on your specific circumstances and the interpretation of Islamic jurisprudence that is followed in your community. 

And remember, in all matters, it's the intention (Niyyah) that counts the most in Islam.
